channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Libyan Militias Set Fire to Storage Tanks in Renewed Push for Oil, Foreign Minister Says
item.description: About 850,000 barrels of oil had been lost because of a fire in five storage tanks, an oil corporation official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Around an Invisible Leader, Taliban Power Shifts
item.description: The reclusiveness of Mullah Muhammad Omar raises questions about the group’s leadership and its influence in the jihadist world next to the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Where Afghan War Was Transferred Long Ago
item.description: The official conclusion of the international combat mission in Afghanistan arrived Sunday, but for the Afghans fighting in this remote border district the symbolic end to America’s 13-year war brought little change.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Gen. John F. Campbell, the top American commander in Afghanistan, rolled up his forces’ flag.

item.title: Bomb in India Kills Woman in Busy Center of Bangalore
item.description: An explosive device that was placed between two flower pots outside a restaurant also wounded a man in an attack the police commissioner said had been “aimed at causing panic and fear.”
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 2014 Proves a Grim Year in Malaysian Aviation
item.description: Should no survivors be found aboard Sunday’s missing AirAsia flight, Malaysian carriers, or their subsidiaries, will have been involved in the world’s three deadliest aviation disasters this year.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: A relative of passengers of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, the plane that disappeared in March, watched a news broadcast about the missing AirAsia Flight 8501 in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: India and the Right to Suicide
item.description: By allowing its citizens the ultimate freedom - the choice to kill oneself - the country becomes a truer democracy.
item.dc:creator: By JERRY PINTO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Caving In to China's Power
item.description: Many of the same leaders who complain about Chinese censorship quietly accept the censorship themselves.
item.dc:creator: By MARK KITTO

item.title: A Former Ground Zero Goes to Court Against the World’s Nuclear Arsenals
item.description: The Marshall Islands, the Pacific atolls where Americans once conducted nuclear tests, want to spur global disarmament in a case before the world’s top court.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:description: A nuclear test in the Marshall Islands, one of 67 conducted by the United States in the area.

item.title: Critic's Notebook: In Haiti, Battling Disease With Open-Air Clinics
item.description: Two new clinics in Haiti for treating cholera and tuberculosis could be models for other struggling countries that lack resources for high-end Western-style hospitals.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

item.title: The Facts on AirAsia Flight 8501
item.description: Nicola Clark, who has written about aviation for The New York Times, offers some background on the flight and how it differs from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Familiar Grief and Mystery After AirAsia Jet Vanishes
item.description: The plane, with 162 on board, left the Indonesian city of Surabaya early Sunday morning for the short hop to Singapore and went missing about 40 minutes later.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Ferry Catches Fire Off Greek Coast With Hundreds on Board
item.description: Rescuers battled rough seas to reach the stricken ferry that caught fire off the northwestern coast of Greece on its way to Italy.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: The ferry Norman Atlantic after it caught fire in the Adriatic Sea on Sunday.

item.title: International Education: For Children in Turkish Refugee Camps, School's Out
item.description: Among the 1.5 million Syrian refugees in tent cities cobbled together near the border are thousands of youths who have lost access to a formal education.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AYSEGUL SERT
item.media:description: Syrian Kurds and their children who had crossed the border to Suruc in Sanliurfa Province, Turkey.

item.title: The Cost of the U.S. Ban on Paying for Hostages
item.description: Former hostages and Syrian rebel commanders say that they offered information they believed could help free American captives, but that officials seemed uninterested.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louai Abo Aljoud, a 23-year-old Syrian journalist who was held with James Foley, outside his home in Gaziantep, Turkey. He says that after he was released, he tried to give American officials information about the prison's location.

item.title: In Reversal, Germany Cools to Russian Investment
item.description: After years of post-Cold War business and political alliances, mistrust over the conflict in Ukraine has created a slew of canceled deals and ventures.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at an annual trade fair in Hanover, Germany in 2013. There is uncertainty hanging over Germany’s strong business ties with Russia, in marked contrast to the optimism and relative stability of recent years.

item.title: AirAsia Flight Said to Be Lost in Indonesia
item.description: Flight QZ8501 was en route from the Indonesian city of Surabaya to Singapore when it requested a “deviation” from its usual flight path because of weather, the airline said. The plane was carrying 155 passengers and seven crew members.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Relatives of the passengers of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 comforted each other at Juanda International Airport in Surabaya, Indonesia, on Sunday.

item.title: As Crisis Saps Economy, Belarus Replaces Premier
item.description: President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus dismissed his prime minister and the head of the country’s central bank on Saturday as part of a sweeping and unexpected government reorganization.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mikhail Myasnikovich in 2013, before his dismissal by the Belarussian president.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Facebook Deletes Post on Tibetan Monk’s Self-Immolation
item.description: Tsering Woeser, a writer in Sichuan Province and prominent critic of Chinese policies toward Tibetans, said Facebook deleted her post on the self-immolation of the 37-year-old monk Kalsang Yeshi, without explanation.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sweden Strikes Deal to Avoid Vote Expected to Strengthen Far Right
item.description: Sweden’s mainstream political parties announced a deal on Saturday to preserve a minority center-left government by adopting the center-right’s budget for next year.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In Limbo, a City in China Faces Life After Graft
item.description: The town of Lüliang in Shanxi Province, whose coal helped fuel China’s economic boom, is at the center of a crackdown that challenges the close ties between business and government.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
